Award.AwardTitle: GPU-based matrix condensation with sparse matrix techniques for power system simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
GPU-based matrix condensation with sparse matrix techniques for power system simulation

The objective of this research is to efficiently solve a fundamental linear algebraic problem, Ax=b, using graphics processing unit (GPU) in combination with matrix condensation (MC) and sparse matrix techniques for fundamental power system analyses. The approach is based on the GPU architecture with the MC method, which has a potential to achieve dimensionally higher performance speedup than the conventional LU factorization method on the GPU architecture, although MC is slower than LU factorization in sequential computing. Further, sparse matrix techniques such as bus re-ordering will be explored in this project and applied to power system simulation.
The intellectual merit includes: investigation of the GPU-based MC algorithm to solve a linear system Ax=b; re-ordering techniques based on GPU and MC to address sparse matrices; combination of GPU, MC and sparsity techniques to give a new solution to power system simulation problems such as power flow, optimal power flow, and stability analysis.
The broader impacts may penetrate into numerous research communities since the solution to Ax=b can be essential to almost every engineering and science discipline. Also, the sparsity techniques combined with the GPU-based MC algorithm can lead to practical applications for power system simulation with significant speedup, such that faster-than-real-time simulation may be easily achieved for post-fault real-time analysis. Thus, it can be highly possible to develop real-time corrective controls with precision, and power systems can be operated closer to security margins. This will provide significant technology advancement towards a smarter power grid.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to explore the linear system solutions with the integration of graphic processing unit (GPU) and to apply them to electric power system computations considering sparse matrix techniques due to the sparse nature of the matrices in power systems.

Iterative solvers are generally more scalable than direct solvers for solving linear equations in parallel architectures, and preconditioners can help the iterative solvers to converge faster. In this project, first, a GPU-based two-step preconditioner combining Jacobi and Chebyshev methods is developed with the conjugate gradient solver to achieve a better performance than can be achieved using each of the preconditioners alone. A quick estimation method for the largest eigenvalue, a critical parameter for Chebyshev preconditioning, is proposed and implemented in the project. Then, this conjugate gradient iterative solver with two-step preconditioner on GPU is further integrated with the fast decoupled power flow (FDPF) algorithm to perform power flow analysis, which is the most fundamental computation in electric power systems. In the integrated algorithm, with the consideration of the features of both GPU and FDPF, the matrices required in FDPF are sent to GPU and stay on GPU for the entire lifetime of the FDPF computation. Such architecture can significantly reduce the communication time between CPU and GPU.

Further, an inexact linear solution method is combined with the conjugate gradient solver to reduce the computation time spent on the linear solution. The FDPF method is essentially a Newton-Raphson method, which itself is an iterative solving process as well. Thus, each linear solution inside of the Newton-Raphson iteration does not have to be precisely solved to continue the Newton-Raphson iteration. As a result, a relaxed threshold is applied for the inner iterative linear solver to avoid excessive precision in the Newton-Raphson iteration. Computing experiments are carried out at several real-world large-scale power systems in the range of 1000 to 10,000 buses. The test results show that the GPU-based FDPF implementation in MATLAB gives almost 3 times speedup if compared with the FDPF computation in a widely used, well-tuned, open-source software package based on MATLAB.

Further, a demonstration Web site has been developed for education, outreach. and dissemination of research results. A number of REU (research experience for undergraduate) students and senior design students participated in this research.

The solution in this project can benefit not only the power flow computation, but also numerous computations and analyses based on power flow, such as N-1 contingency analysis and optimal power flow. Other than the electric power system applications, it can also be extended to other fields using the Newton method for solving nonlinear systems. Thus, this project demonstrates important outcomes and broad potentials in using GPUs for electrical power system applications and other scientific and engineering fields.
